summary: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a type of head and neck cancer originating in the nasopharynx. It is characterized by its distinct occurrence, causes, clinical behavior, and treatment compared to other head and neck cancers. NPC is significantly more common in certain regions of East Asia and Africa and is more prevalent in males. It is a squamous cell carcinoma of an undifferentiated type.
causes: Consumption of preserved meats and salted fish containing carcinogenic volatile nitrosamines
Human papillomavirus (HPV) (for WHO type I NPC)
risk_factors: Living in crowded and less hygienic conditions (for EBV transmission)
symptoms: Lump or mass on the back of the neck (often not tender or painful)
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Sore throat that does not go away
Nasal regurgitation due to paresis of the soft palate
diagnosis: Staging based on clinical and radiologic examination
treatments: Radiation therapy (including 3D conformal radiation therapy, intensity-modulated radiation therapy, particle beam therapy, brachytherapy)
Immunotherapy (e.g., toripalimab-tpzi with cisplatin and gemcitabine)
